questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with complaints of dysphagia, fever, stridor, drooling, and muffled voice. The following image is seen on a lateral x-ray of the neck. What is the finding seen in the given radiograph?
questions.solution:
Thumb sign is seen on the given lateral view radiograph.

The above clinical features of a toxic looking child with high-grade fever, tachypnea, stridor, dysphagia with salivary drooling are suggestive of acute epiglottitis. Thumb sign on lateral X-ray of neck is pathognomonic for acute epiglottitis. 

Acute epiglottitis is an acute rapidly progressive confined to supraglottic structures i.e., epiglottis, aryepiglottic fold and arytenoids. It usually affects children of age 2-7 years. It has a potentially fulminating course of fever, sore throat, dyspnea, and rapidly progressing respiratory obstruction.

Management:

Indirect laryngoscopy shows edema and congestion of supraglottic structures. A lateral X-ray of the neck shows swollen epiglottis giving an appearance called the thumb sign.

Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency due to sudden and unpredictable airway obstruction. The treatment includes the following:

  • Admission to ICU
  • Airway management - endotracheal intubation, tracheostomy for respiratory obstruction
  • Antibiotics - Ampicillin or third-generation cephalosporin is indicated in the treatment of acute epiglottitis along with airway management.
  • Dexamethasone may be given to reduce pharyngeal edema

Other options:

Option A: Steeple sign is seen in laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

Option C- Below image shows adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option D- Omega shaped epiglottis is seen in laryngomalacia. This finding is seen in direct laryngoscopy.

Related Pearl: Acute stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane, and un-immunized
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A patient presents with diffuse abdominal pain, and on examination, there is generalised tenderness along with board-like abdominal rigidity. An X-ray of the abdomen is provided. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the chest radiograph showing air under the diaphragm are suggestive of a hollow viscus perforation resulting in perforation peritonitis.

Perforation of a viscus is a life-threatening condition that occurs following the rupture of the alimentary tract. This leads to the leakage of the enteric contents, thereby leading to acute bacterial peritonitis. Peritonitis is the generalized or localized inflammation of the peritoneum either due to the free spillage of fluids into the peritoneal cavity or secondary bacterial infection.

Clinical features of hollow viscous perforation occur due to the developed peritonitis and the features include abdominal pain and distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, decreased or absent bowel sounds, and guarding on palpation. Fever may be present. Sometimes, features of septic shock can be seen at later stages.

Investigations include estimating the white blood cell count, urea, serum electrolytes, and an erect abdominal radiograph showing free gas under the diaphragm. A supine radiograph may show dilated gas-filled loops of the bowel, suggestive of paralytic ileus. The below image shows a hollow viscus perforation.

Management of a hollow viscous perforation is mainly resuscitation, analgesics, intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics, and emergency laparotomy. Peritonitis is managed by nutritional support, pain relief, correction of fluid loss and circulating volume, urinary catheterization with or without gastrointestinal compression, antibiotics, analgesics, and specific surgical treatment of the cause.

Other Options: 

Option A: Clinical presentation of acute pancreatitis is characterized by epigastric pain radiating to the back which is relieved by bending forward, nausea, and vomiting. 

Option C: Duodenal ulcer pain occurs 1.5 to 3 hours after a meal and is frequently relieved by antacids or food. Gastric Ulcer pain/discomfort may be precipitated by food. Nausea and weight loss are common.

Option D: A hiatal hernia occurs when a portion of the stomach pushes through the diaphragm into the chest cavity. It can cause symptoms such as heartburn, regurgitation, and chest pain, and may require medical or surgical treatment.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman presents with a history of pain in the forearm after falling down the stairs. X-ray is done and is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray are most suggestive of Colles’ fracture.

The radiograph shows a transverse fracture of the radius just above the wrist. The fracture appears extra-articular. In the AP-view, the distal fracture fragment is dorsally angulated. This is characteristic of Colles' fracture.  

Displacements that may be seen in Colles' fracture:

  • Dorsal tilt
  • Dorsal shift
  • Lateral tilt (Radial tilt)
  • Lateral shift (Radial shift)
  • Supination
  • Impaction of fragments

The clinical feature includes dinner fork deformity with prominence on the back of the wrist and depression in the front. It is treated by a Colles’ cast, which immobilizes the wrist in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.

questions.text: A patient after a motor vehicle accident develops breathing difficulty. On examination, there are decreased breath sounds on the right side, and the trachea is shifted to the left. Heart sounds are normal. There is a dull note on percussion. The chest X-ray is shown below. What will be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Decreased breath sounds, tracheal deviation to the opposite side, dull note on percussion, and the chest X-ray showing blunting of the costophrenic angle and opacification is suggestive of massive hemothorax. The next step of management that can be done for this patient is intercostal drainage tube(ICD) placement.

Massive hemothorax occurs when more than 1500 mL of blood, equivalent to one-third or more of the patient's blood volume, rapidly accumulates in the chest cavity. This condition is typically caused by a penetrating injury that damages major blood vessels, although it can also be the result of blunt trauma.

In patients with massive hemothorax, the neck veins may appear flat due to severe hypovolemia, or they may be distended if there is a concurrent tension pneumothorax. If a patient is in shock and exhibits an absence of breath sounds or dullness upon percussion on one side of the chest, it suggests the presence of a massive hemothorax.

The initial management of massive hemothorax involves simultaneous resuscitation to restore blood volume and decompression of the chest cavity. This is achieved by establishing large-diameter intravenous lines, administering crystalloid fluids, and initiating transfusion of blood at the earliest opportunity. A single chest tube with a diameter of 28-32 French is inserted, typically at the fifth intercostal space, just anterior to the midaxillary line. Volume restoration is rapidly continued while the chest cavity is decompressed.

The immediate return of 1500 mL or greater volume of blood typically signifies the urgent requirement for thoracotomy. Patients who initially show an output of less than 1500 mL of fluid but continue to bleed may also necessitate thoracotomy.

Needle thoracostomy and open thoracostomy are done in cases of tension pneumothorax. Here, the patients present with distended neck veins, decreased breath sounds, tracheal deviation to the opposite side, and hyper-resonant note on percussion. 

Pericardiocentesis is done in cases of cardiac tamponade. Here, the patients present with distended neck veins, normal breath sounds, and muffled heart sounds. There is no mediastinal shift here.

questions.text: A patient visits your clinic for follow-up after a breast surgery. She undergoes an x-ray scan, the findings of which are given below. Which of the following complications, if present in this patient, would show the linguine sign on MRI?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows silicone breast implants in a patient. MRI showing the linguine sign in post-silicone breast implant patients indicates intra-capsular silicone rupture.

After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around the implant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by the fibrous scar, while the shell appears as a group of wavy lines. This has been termed the linguine sign. It is seen in intra-capsular rupture of a breast implant.

Multiple hyperintense foci on T2-weighted images are sometimes found within the implant lumen. These findings are referred to as the “salad oil sign” or “droplet sign”.

Intracapsular rupture on MRI.

Breast implants are technically simple and it facilitates achieving symmetry. The implant in submuscular plane is better whenever a muscle is not removed during surgery. If the muscle is removed as in radical mastectomy, then a subcutaneous implant is placed. Silicone gel implants are used.

Complications may include pain, exposure of implant and rupture, infection, calcifications, displacements, intracapsular or extracapsular rupture and silicone granulomas.

MRI  of the breast can be used in the following cases:

  • To detect scar recurrence in women with a history of conservative breast surgery  
  • To assess the extent of high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)
  • To assess multifocality and multicentricity in lobular cancer 
  • It is the best imaging modality for women with breasts implants
  • As a screening tool in high-risk women with a positive family history.

Generally, ultrasound(USG) is the preferred modality of imaging in suspected cases of extracapsular rupture. The Snowstorm sign on USG is seen in extracapsular rupture. (Option-B)

Other options:

Option B: In the case of extracapsular rupture of the silicone implant, it is detected by snowstorm appearance on USG.

Option C: Risk of anaplastic large cell lymphoma of scar tissue is increased in breast implant patients. This is confirmed by biopsy.

Option D: Calcifications in post-implant surgery patients can be detected on X-ray film. MRI used to detect contractures.

The given image below shows the siliconoma on silicone breast implants and the HP section shows silicone granulomas following silicone leak:

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is shown in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The given image is a double contrast radiograph of barium meal. It is used to examine the lower half of the esophagus, stomach, and entire duodenum.

GI Imaging Preparations of barium Structures best visualized
Barium swallow Barium paste Esophagus
Barium meal 95% BaSO4 Stomach and duodenum
Barium meal follow-through 50% BaSO4 Small bowel
Barium enema 25% BaSO4 Large bowel

The below radiograph shows a barium follow-through study. It is useful in visualizing small bowel pathology and evaluating the function of the small bowel. It is inferior to enteroclysis enema where contrast is administered through a nasogastric tube.

The below radiograph is a double-contrast barium enema with a normal large bowel structure. The contrast is administered through a rectal tube and a series of radiographs are obtained.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presented with recurrent bilious vomiting. An X-ray erect abdomen is given below. What is the next best step in managing this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history along with the radiograph showing the triple bubble sign implies a diagnosis of jejunal atresia. A contrast study is the next best investigation to exclude other large bowel anomalies.

Small bowel atresias present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth. 

  • Bilious vomiting is the dominant feature in jejunal atresia
  • Abdominal distension is more prominent with ileal atresia.

A small amount of pale meconium may be passed despite the atresia. 

Plain abdominal radiographs show a variable number of dilated loops of bowel and fluid levels according to the level of obstruction. A contrast enema study can demonstrate a narrow calibre of colon and may also be useful to exclude multiple atresias, which may be present in 10% to 15% of cases.

In most cases of jejunal/ileal atresia, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is done. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman had her routine follow up and her USG of the liver is shown below. She is asymptomatic at present but has a history of mild right hypochondriac pain which is relieved by taking analgesics. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The USG shows a gallbladder wall that is thickened with no edema in the pericholecystic fat. The gallbladder contains biliary sludge and gallstones, shown as the acoustic shadowing. There are no signs of current cholecystitis and thus the diagnosis is gallstones.

Ultrasonography is the most accurate initial imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of gallbladder stones. They appear as echogenic foci producing acoustic shadows. Size of the gallbladder, presence of stones or polyps, and the thickness of the wall are measured. Inflammation around the gallbladder, the size of the common bile duct, and stones in the extrahepatic biliary tree can also be determined. The sensitivity of UG is > 95%. Small stones can be differentiated from small polyps by the presence of mobility or of an acoustic shadow. 

The image below shows ultrasonography of the gall bladder:  

Amoebic liver abscess ( Option b)  shows necrotic material and debris on usg without any acoustic shadows. Diagnosis is often found using aspiration.

 

Hydatid cysts (option c) can present similarly. There is tenderness and enlargement of the liver with blood investigations show eosinophilia, elevated liver enzymes. USG can show various stages, classical being multiple septations and rosette or honeycomb appearance, Water Lilly sign when the cyst wall detaches

The image below shows the multiple septations in ultrasonography of hydatid cyst.

An ultrasound scan in acute cholecystitis (Option d ) demonstrates a distended gallbladder with a thickened wall of >3 mm, pericholecystic fluid, the presence of gallstone( when it is due to associated cholelithiasis), and the sonographic Murphy's sign. Gallbladder distension (diameter >5 cm), pericholecystic fluid, gallbladder wall striations, and, occasionally, wall hyperemia on Doppler examination may also be seen in USG.

questions.text: CT done for a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of sterile pyuria with CT showing right-sided putty kidney points to renal tuberculosis. 

Putty kidney refers to the amorphous dystrophic calcification seen over the entire kidney during the end stage of genitourinary TB. 

Genitourinary tuberculosis is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream. It occurs either due to reinfection or reactivation of old TB.

CT is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. CT urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB. 

ATT is given to all patients with genitourinary TB. Nephrectomy is the preferred treatment in patients with putty/ cement kidneys.

Option D: Nephrocalcinosis refers to the deposition of calcium salts in the kidney parenchyma and tubules.

questions.text: A male patient is brought unresponsive to the emergency room following trauma to the head. CT head is shown below. What is the definitive management for his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing lens-shaped hemorrhage is consistent with acute epidural hematoma. Craniotomy with emergency evacuation of the hematoma is the definitive management of this condition.

Extradural hematoma (EDH) is also known as an epidural hematoma. It is a collection of blood between the outer layer of the dura and the inner surface of the skull which is called the periosteal layer. The bleeding is most commonly due to torn middle meningeal artery.

EDH is commonly associated with a history of trauma and associated skull fracture.  It is associated with an underlying fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone.

Epidural hematoma may present with a transient loss of consciousness immediately following the trauma followed by a lucid interval, where consciousness is recovered. The patient subsequently worsens his neurological status due to continued bleeding from the site as seen in this patient. It can cause a mass effect with herniation

EDH is diagnosed with CT and MRI. CT image shows the typical bi-convex hyperdense lesion not crossing cranial sutures, but can cross venous sinuses.

The definitive management for any patient with GCS<9 and pupillary abnormalities such as anisocoria is craniotomy with emergency evacuation of the hematoma. Surgery is also recommended for patients with worsening neurological status and hematoma volume >30ml regardless of neurological status

Other options:

Option A: Hyperventilation lowers the pCO2 and lowers the intracranial pressure (ICP) because of vasoconstriction. But this may also worsen the perfusion in the brain and must be done with caution.

Option B: Intravenous mannitol may be used to lower ICP but it is not a definitive management option in this patient in a coma.

Option D: Anticoagulants are not administered in cases of EDH, especially if surgery is needed or there's a risk of ongoing bleeding. This is because anticoagulants can increase the risk of bleeding, which can exacerbate the situation in cases of traumatic brain injury.

questions.text: The Money bag heart is seen in:
questions.solution:
The Money bag heart is seen in pericardial effusion.

Plain PA chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette. There is effacement of the normal cardiac borders, development of a ‘flask’ or ‘water bottle’ cardiac configuration and bilateral hilar overlay which are features of pericardial effusion. It is also known as Money bag or leather bottle-shaped heart.

Investigation of choice: Echocardiography.

Signs on plain radiograph include:

  • Globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow giving a water bottle configuration.
  • Lateral CXR may show a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line directly behind the sternum (paracardial fat) anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical lucent line (epicardial fat) posteriorly; this is known as the Oreo cookie sign.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood-stained stools. The barium study of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiological images are suggestive of intussusception.

In intussusception, the occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen has been termed the coiled spring appearance (barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space). In adults, it develops due to a tumor of the bowel.

The intussusception appears as a sausage-shaped mass in a longitudinal plane or a target mass in the transverse plane on CT and USG. 

Ultrasound signs include:

  • Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)
  • Pseudokidney sign- this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel
    • the edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and
    • the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Option B: Volvulus presents with constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea, and/or vomiting. It shows coffee bean sign

Option C: Diverticulitis presents with pain in the left iliac fossa

Option D: Ulcerative colitis causes backwash ileitis

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of tuberculosis presents with dyspnea on exertion. On examination, it is noted that the JVP rises during inspiration. A chest radiograph of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of tuberculosis now presenting with positive Kussmaul's sign, and pericardial calcification seen on chest radiograph suggest a diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis. 

Constrictive pericarditis is a chronic type of pericarditis that results when there is healing of acute fibrinous pericarditis or absorption of chronic pericardial effusion. While the most common cause in developing countries is tuberculosis, in developed countries, it occurs following viral pericarditis, cardiac surgery, mediastinal irradiation, or as a manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis and SLE. The main abnormality which occurs in constrictive pericarditis is the inability of the ventricles to fill because of the rigid and thickened pericardium. Unlike tamponade, this restriction is not uniform through the diastole. Ventricular filling is normal early in the diastole but stops suddenly when the elastic limit of the pericardium is reached. Y-descent on the JVP curve is prominent in constrictive pericarditis because it represents the rapid early filling of the ventricles. A sudden stop in ventricular filling and subsequent rising pressure is seen as a square root sign in the JVP curve.

The patient presents with exertional dyspnea and orthopnea. There may be a paradoxical rise in venous pressure during inspiration (Kussmaul's sign). Apart from constrictive pericarditis, Kussmaul's sign can be positive in tricuspid stenosis, restrictive cardiomyopathy, right heart failure, and pulmonary embolism. The ECG often shows low-voltage QRS complexes and diffuse flattening of T-waves. A chest radiograph may show pericardial calcification, especially in tuberculous pericarditis.

questions.text: A neonate presented with mild intermittent upper abdominal pain. On examination, the infant has a scaphoid abdomen and breath sounds are decreased on both sides. X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of respiratory distress, intermittent abdominal pain, scaphoid abdomen, absent breath sounds in both sides of the chest, and an X-ray image showing bowel loops in the thoracic cavity is diagnostic of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), the most common variant being Bochdalek hernia.

If the defect is posterolateral it is called Bochdalek hernia and if it's anteromedial it is called Morgagni hernia. 

Clinical features :

  • Respiratory distress is a cardinal sign in infants with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
  • Early respiratory distress, within 6 hr after birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.
  • Children with CDH may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter.
  • Bowel sounds may also be heard in the chest, with a bilateral decrease in breath sounds.
  • The point of maximal cardiac impulse may be displaced away from the side of a hernia if a mediastinal shift has occurred.
  • Retroperitoneal fat, left kidney, spleen or only the omentum commonly herniates through the defect. If the defect is large, most abdominal contents including the stomach may herniate.

Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiography and passage of a nasal gastric tube confirm the diagnosis.
  • CDH can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography (between 16 and 24 weeks of gestation)
  • High-speed fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can further define the lesion.

Treatment:

Variable period of time (24-72 hours) to allow for stabilization before surgical repair. Immediate respiratory support should be provided, including rapid endotracheal intubation and sedation. 

Bag and Mask Ventilation is contraindicated in newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia because it causes distension of the stomach which in turn may limit the expansion of the already hypoplastic lung.

Other options:

Option B: Chest radiograph revealing bowel loops in the thorax is not seen in pneumonia.

Option C: Morgagni hernia: Here the defect is at the anteromedial location. It is rarer than Bochdalek hernia and accounts for only 2-5% of CDH. About 90% of the cases occur on the right side.

It is less symptomatic and the diagnosis is usually delayed until childhood. The patient presents with respiratory or upper GI symptoms. Respiratory symptoms like distress, tachypnea, and recurrent pulmonary infections are common in children. Other symptoms are abdominal pain, dyspnea, flatulence, and indigestion.

Radiographic findings

  • Radiolucent paracardiac shadow may be seen retrosternally on lateral chest x-ray if there is bowel herniation.
  • Rounded opacity in the right cardiophrenic angle may be seen if there is herniation of omentum or solid organs.(Shown below)

 

Option D: Eventration of the diaphragm: It refers to the abnormal contour of the dome of the diaphragm without any disruption to the diaphragmatic continuity. It usually involves a segment of the hemidiaphragm. It can cause respiratory distress in newborns and is usually asymptomatic in adults.

Radiographic findings: The affected portion of the hemidiaphragm is elevated and is seen as a smooth hump, while the normal contour is seen in the remaining part. 'Double diaphragmatic contour' may be seen in frontal view and is confirmed with a lateral X-ray.

questions.text: A mother with polyhydramnios delivered a baby at term gestation. The baby chokes on the milk at every attempt, and on examination, the abdomen is distended and vesicular breath sounds are heard in bilateral lung fields. An attempt to pass a nasogastric tube fails. An X-ray is ordered and appears as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms of choking and abdominal distention with a failure to pass a nasogastric tube and an X-ray showing NG tube in proximal esophagus and stomach distended with gas suggests the presence of a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).

A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal fistula communication between the esophagus and trachea. Among the different types, Type C is the most common type. It consists of proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF. With each breath, the air enters the distal esophagus and the stomach causing gastric distention which presents as abdominal distention. 

Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube is a crucial pointer in the diagnosis of esophageal atresia. 

Tracheoesophageal fistula is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies.

Other options:

Option A: Foreign body in the trachea will present with decreased air entry bilaterally in the lungs and stridor.

Option B: Gastric volvulus may also be associated with abdominal distension and difficulty in passing the NG tube into the stomach. However, in this case, the tube is seen stuck in the proximal esophagus itself making the diagnosis of TEF more likely.

Option D: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is usually left-sided and presents with respiratory distress. On examination, bowel sounds are heard in the chest field as abdominal contents herniate into the chest. There is a scaphoid abdomen rather than a distended abdomen as in this case.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheoesophageal Fistula

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of spontaneous nasal bleeding. There is no history of trauma or fall. He gives a history of unilateral nasal obstruction and denasal speech. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is taken, which is shown below. What is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus is called the antral sign or Holman-Miller sign.

The given clinical picture along with a CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma commonly arising from the sphenopalatine foramen. 

From here, the tumor grows into the

  • Nasal cavity
  • Nasopharynx
  • Pterygopalatine fossa
  • Pterygomaxillary fossa
  • Infratemporal fossa

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor predominant in adolescent males in the age group of 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity that is close to the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen. These patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx that forms angiofibroma when testosterone appears. Therefore, it is thought to be testosterone-dependent.

Angiofibroma can extend into the nasal cavity causing obstruction, epistaxis, paranasal sinuses, pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa, cheek, orbits causing proptosis, frog-face deformity, and cranial cavity. The clinical features include:

  • Profuse, recurrent, spontaneous epistaxis- most common
  • Progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech- due to mass in the postnasal space
  • Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion- due to obstruction of the eustachian tube
  • Sessile, lobulated, or smooth mass in the nasopharynx
  • Other clinical features include the broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis, cheek swelling, involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth, and VIth cranial nerves

Diagnosis is based on the clinical picture. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is the investigation of choice that reveals anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (antral sign/Holman-Miller sign) which is pathognomonic of angiofibroma as shown below.

MRI can also be done that reveals soft tissue extensions. Carotid angiography is also done which shows the extent of the tumor with its vascularity. The feeding vessels mostly come from the external carotid artery. In large tumors with intracranial extension, vessels come from the internal carotid system also. Biopsy of the mass is avoided due to the risk of bleeding.

Given below is a CT image showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus - antral sign or Holman-Miller sign.

 

Staging of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

Stage Spread
IA Limited to the nose and/or nasopharynx
IB Extension into ≥ one paranasal sinus
IIA Minimal extension into the sphenopalatine foramen with minimal part of pterygopalatine fossa
IIB Full occupation of pterygopalatine fossa with Holman-Miller sign, may with an erosion of orbital bones
IIC Extension into the cheek, temporal fossa, or posterior to pterygoids through the pterygomaxillary fossa
IIIA Erosion of skull base with minimal intracranial
IIIB Erosion of skull base with extensive intracranial with or without cavernous sinus

Treatment: Surgical approach is the treatment of choice. Embolization of the vessels can be done prior to surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding during the surgery. Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy can also be considered.

Other options:

Option A: Aquino sign is the blanching of the tumor mass in the glomus tumor when the ipsilateral carotid artery is compressed manually.

Option C & D: Hanging drop/tear-drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum.

questions.text: A woman with a history of infertility is on treatment with HMG. She presented with the following finding in the USG. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the USG findings are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is characterized by mul­tiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability. It most often is a complication of ovulation­ induction therapy for infertility, although it may rarely develop in an otherwise normal pregnancy. It has also been reported with a partial molar pregnancy. Its etiopatho­genesis is thought to involve the stimulation of vascular endo­thelial growth factor (VEGF) expression in granulosa-lutein cells by hCG.

Human menopausal gonadotropin (HMG) is a medication that is composed of FSH and LH. It is used to stimulate the release of ova in women who do not ovulate spontaneously. It can lead to ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

Related Pearl: Management of female infertility for different causes are as follows

Etiology Investigations Management  
Tubal cause
  • Hysterosalpingography or sonosalpingography
  • Falloscopy
  • Salpingography
  • Laparoscopic chemotubation
  • Laparoscopic adhesiolysis
  • Tuboplasty
  • Hysteroscopic cannulation and balloonplasty
  • If all the above procedures fail or not feasible go for IVF/GIFT 
Ovulation related           
  • Ovulation monitoring by ultrasound (BBT, BBI) And  Endometrial Biopsy for tuberculosis done    
  • If the above steps are abnormal, do a hormonal study
  • FSH, LH, Prolactin
  • E2, P level
  • Thyroid and diabetes
  • Clomiphene and letrozole
  • If it fails, give FSH, LH, GnRH
  • Check for a response; if there is no response do IVF Donor egg.
  • If all the above measures fail, the final option is to adopt  
Other causes   Ultrasound, MRI, SSG, hysteroscopy   Treat the cause

questions.text: Xray of a 2 year old child is given, what is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows "football sign" which is seen in the pneumoperitoneum.

Football sign-the abdominal cavity is outlined by gas from a perforated viscus, seen in massive pneumoperitoneum.

Causes of pneumoperitoneum include:

  • Bowel perforation
    1. Peptic ulcer
    2. Ischemic bowel
    3. Necrotizing enterocolitis
  • Small bowel perforation
    1. Trauma
    2. Penetrating injuries
  • During surgery/laparoscopy

Radiological signs in pneumoperitoneum include:

  • Bowel related signs
    • Double-wall sign (also known as Rigler's sign): Both the outer and inner walls of the bowel are visible.
    • Telltale triangle sign (also known as triangle sign): A radiolucent triangle of gas between three loops of bowel or between two loops of bowel and the abdominal wall.
  • Peritoneal ligament related signs
    • Football sign -the abdominal cavity is outlined by gas from a perforated viscus, seen in massive pneumoperitoneum.
    • Falciform ligament sign - Falciform or medial umbilical ligaments may be seen due to free gas on either side of the ligaments. 
    • Lateral umbilical ligament sign (also known as inverted "V" sign) - Free gas routines the lateral umbilical ligament.
    • Urachus sign
  • Right upper quadrant signs
    • Morison's pouch sign - a triangular area of gas in the right upper quadrant, usually bound by the 11th rib in the right upper quadrant in the area of Morrison's pouch.
    • Cupola sign - Gas under the right and left hemidiaphragm joining in the midline. Seen on chest X-ray.
    • Fissure for ligamentum teres sign
    • Hepatic edge sign
    • Lucent liver sign
    • Periportal free gas sign

Rigler's sign-

Falciform ligament sign.

Cupola sign-

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to you with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. The X-ray appearance of his left hip joint is shown in the below image. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and trethowan's sign seen in the x-ray are suggestive of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

The Klein line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck which normally intersects the epiphysis. In SCFE, Klein's line does not intersect the epiphysis and passes superior to it. This is known as Trethowan's sign.

Slipped femoral capital epiphysis (SCFE) occurs during a period of rapid growth with the average age of presentation around 12 years.

Risk factors: Obesity, hypothyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all-important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features:

  • Patients with SCFE typically present in the rapid growth phase of adolescence with pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.
  • On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated.
  • There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side.
  • Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign.
  • Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Other radiological findings include:

  • Wide or irregular physis with loss of the anterior head-neck concavity
  • Sharp metaphyseal border of the head
  • Loss of total epiphyseal height
  • Steel sign (Metaphyseal blanch sign) - The posteriorly displaced femoral epiphysis overlaps over the metaphysis causing a crescent-shaped area of increased density on the AP radiograph.
  • Capener’s sign –the metaphysis displaces laterally, worsening the slip and causes a reduction in the double-density crescent created by the overlap of the posterior acetabulum and proximal metaphysis on the AP radiograph.
  • Southwick angle – The angle between the line drawn perpendicular to the physis and a line parallel to the femoral shaft. As slip worsens, the Southwick angle will increase. It is measured on the frog lateral X-ray view.

Other options:

Perthes disease:

It is characterized by idiopathic avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. This condition commonly affects children of 4-8 years of age. The child has pain in the hip while performing passive movements. The radiograph shows features of bone necrosis followed by remodeling.

Developmental Dysplasia of the hip: It is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. This condition is more common in females. Children with this condition have a waddling gait and on examination abduction and lateral rotation of the hip are decreased. X-ray shows a broken Shenton's line and the femoral head lies in the upper and outer quadrants formed by Hilgenreiner’s line and Perkin’s line.

The image given below shows the vertical Perkin's line and the horizontal Hilgenreiner's line. Normally the femoral head lies in the inner and lower quadrant formed by these lines. But in DDH the femoral head is in the upper and outer quadrant.

Ankylosing spondylitis: It is a chronic progressive inflammatory condition affecting the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton. It is commonly seen in young male adults and they typically present with an insidious onset back pain that improves with exercise. The earliest radiological finding is erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints and the characteristic late sign is the bamboo-spine appearance.

X-ray showing bamboo-spine appearance-

questions.text: A 56-year-old​ female patient presented with progressive dysphagia for solids, loss of weight, and loss of appetite. A barium swallow done is given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Dysphagia is the most common earliest presenting symptom
The squamous cell variant usually affects the upper two-thirds and the adenocarcinoma variant usually affects the lower third
Common aetiological factors are tobacco and alcohol
The incidence of adenocarcinoma is increasing

questions.solution:
The given barium study shows irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins which is suggestive of carcinoma esophagus. Dysphagia is the most common presenting symptom but is a late feature in carcinoma esophagus.

Esophageal carcinoma is more commonly seen in men. Tobacco use and alcohol are strong risk factors. Adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus are the two most common types. The squamous cell variant usually affects the upper two-thirds and the adenocarcinoma variant usually affects the lower third. The incidence of adenocarcinoma is increasing.

Clinical features include:

  • Dysphagia (most common)
  • Regurgitation
  • Vomiting
  • Odynophagia
  • Weight loss

In the advanced stage, there can be hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, horner’s syndrome, chronic spinal pain, and diaphragmatic paralysis.

Flexible endoscopy with biopsy is preferred for confirmation of diagnosis. Other investigations include barium swallow, which shows a rat-tail appearance due to irregular narrowing or ulceration. Contrast-enhanced CT and PET can be used to assess distant metastasis. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is the investigation of choice to assess tumor invasion and lymph node metastasis.

questions.text: A newborn is seen to have an abnormal lump in the lower back. Identify the condition from the MRI given below.
questions.solution:
The MRI given represents meningocele. 

Meningocele involves the midline protrusion of the meninges. A fluctuant midline mass, that may transilluminate is present in the lower back along the vertebral column. Meningomyelocele involves the protrusion of the spinal cord with the meningeal covering. Neurological dysfunction is more common in these open defects.

Spina bifida occulta refers to fusion defects of the posterior part of the vertebral body. There is no associated protrusion of the spinal cord or meninges. These neonates are usually asymptomatic, without any neurological signs. They present only with a tuft of hair over the lower back. 

The image below shows (from left to right) spina bifida occulta, meningocele, and meningomyelocele-

questions.text: X-ray of a patient who had a history of RTA appears as below. What is the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Right pneumothorax with right lung collapse and right tracheal shift
Right pneumothorax with right lung collapse and left tracheal shift
Right pneumothorax with left lung collapse and left tracheal shift
Right pneumothorax with left lung collapse  and right tracheal shift

questions.solution:
The image shows a right pneumothorax with collapsed right lung and tracheal deviation to the left.

Pneumothorax refers to the presence of gas (air) in the pleural space. When there is a progressive accumulation of intrapleural gas in the thoracic cavity (caused by a valve effect during inspiration and expiration) it is called a tension pneumothorax. It can result in the compression of mediastinal structures and compromise cardiopulmonary function. It is life-threatening and requires emergency intervention.

It is characterized by:

  • Chest pain.
  • Tachypnoea, and acute dyspnea.
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness).
  • Neck vein distention.
  • Tracheal deviation away from the side of the injury.
  • Decreased chest movements on the affected side.
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side.
  • Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side.

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • Thin, sharp white line, demarcating the visceral pleural edge.
  • Absence of lung markings seen peripheral to this line.
  • Peripheral space radiolucent compared to the adjacent lung. 
  • Lung collapse on the same side of the injury. Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum may be seen.
  • Deep sulcus sign (on supine chest radiograph).

Deep sulcus sign: On a supine film (common in the ICU), air collects anteriorly and basally, within the nondependent portions of the pleural space, as opposed to the apex when the patient is upright. 

The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign. It may be the only indication of a pneumothorax in such patients.

questions.text: Match the following intracranial bleed:
questions.solution:
Epidural hematoma:

Noncontrasted axial computed tomography scan showing a lenticular area of increased density in left parietal region.

  • Typically occur in the groove of the middle meningeal artery associated with temporal bone fractures that have resulted in a tear of middle meningeal artery.
  • They tend to not to cross suture lines of the skull.

Subdural hematoma:

A non contrasted computed tomography scan of acute subdural hematoma shows a cresentric area of increased density in the right posterior parietal region between brain and the skull. An area of intraparenchymal haemorrhage also seen. In addition, mass effect causes a midline shift to left.

  • They can cross suture lines but they do not cross the tentorium or falx.
  • Can be acute or chronic

Subarachnoid haemorrhage:

A non contrasted axial computed tomography scan shows the blood as areas of increased density near the base of the brain shows blood in Texaco star pattern formed blood radiating from suprasellar cistern into the sylvian fissures and anterior interhemispheric fissure.

  • Most often accompanied by severe sudden onset headache.
  • Can really be visualised in acute stage, when blood is radiographically dense (whiter) than the CSF.

Intracereberal haemorrhage:

Non contrast computed tomography shows a large area of fresh blood appearing white in the region of right thalamus. Blood is denser than CSF so settles dependently.

This settling is not seen with subarachnoid or interparenchymal blood.

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: A patient presents with elbow deformity and forearm shortening after a fall. An X-ray was done and given below.  What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and X-ray are suggestive of elbow dislocation. X-ray shows posterior dislocation of the elbow joint. 

Elbow dislocation is the most common dislocation in the pediatric age group and the second most common dislocation after the shoulder in adults.

Posterior dislocation is the commonest type of elbow dislocation. It frequently occurs due to a fall on the outstretched hands with the elbow slightly flexed. Other dislocations are postero-medial, postero-lateral, and divergent.

Anterior dislocation occurs when the elbow is flexed and there is a direct blow on the posterior aspect of the elbow joint.

Clinical features:

  • The forearm appears shortened.
  • Crepitus is absent.
  • The three-point bony relationship is disrupted.
  • Olecranon is above the intercondylar line

Elbow dislocation is an emergency and has to be reduced immediately. Closed reduction under general anaesthesia(GA) is attempted first. An above elbow POP slab is applied with 90º elbow flexion and mid-pronation for a period of 3 weeks after closed reduction under GA.

Stimson’s 2 step principles for closed reduction

  1. Step 1 - traction along the long axis of the humerus to counteract the contraction of biceps, triceps and brachialis
  2. Step 2 - traction along the long axis of the forearm to bring radius and ulna back into position
    2 techniques in closed reduction

Prone technique - Grab the wrist of the injured arm. Apply traction and slight supination to the forearm. Using the other hand, apply pressure to the posterior aspect of the olecranon while the arm is pronated.

Supine technique - a helper stabilizes the humerus against the stretcher with both hands. Grasp the wrist, and apply slow, steady, inline traction, keeping the elbow slightly flexed and the wrist supinated

Complications:

  • Early complications include neurovascular injury. Vascular injuries are rare and involve the brachial artery in open fractures associated with elbow dislocation.
  • Late complications include myositis ossificans, recurrent dislocations, proximal radioulnar translocation, and ectopic calcifications

questions.text: A 22-year-old male on evaluation for intermittent dysphagia shows the following characteristic appearance on barium swallow. The probable diagnosis is______.
questions.solution:
The barium swallow shows a thin circumferential ring in the distal esophagus, which is suggestive of Schatzki’s ring.

Schatzki’s ring:

  • Schatzki’s ring is a circular ring in the distal esophagus (squamocolumnar junction) associated with gastroesophageal reflux disorder (GERD).
  • Concentric, nonmalignant, fibrous thickening and narrowing of the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ), with squamous epithelium above and columnar cells below.
  • The core of the ring consists of variable amounts of fibrous tissue and cellular infiltrate.
  • The cause is unknown, and correlations to reflux disease and hiatal hernia are still debatable. 
  • It may cause dysphagia.
  • Treatment is endoscopic dilation with antireflux therapy.

questions.text:
Match the following radiograph images with their views.
  1. Submentovertical view
  2. Caldwell view
  3. Water's view
  4. Towne's view
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pair is 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a.

1 c. Water's view
2 b. Caldwell view
3 d. Towne's view
4 a. Submentovertical view

Waters' view (also known as the Occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is a radiographic view, where an X-ray beam is angled at 37° to the orbitomeatal line. The rays are passed from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

  • It is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses.

Structures observed:

  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (through open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone

Caldwell's view (also known as the occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is a radiographic view of the skull, where the X-ray plate is angled at 15° to the orbito-meatal line. The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

  • It is commonly used to get a better view of frontal sinuses.

Structures seen are: 

  • Frontal sinuses 
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

The image below shows Caldwell's view 

Towne's view: 

It is taken with the patient in the supine position and lying on his back with the chin often depressed into the neck. The X-ray camera is angled at 30 degrees towards the feet so that the rays enter the head at the level of the hairline.

  • This is usually taken for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.
  • Bilateral petrous pyramids are visible in this view and hence can be compared.
Structures seen are:
  • Arcuate eminence and superior semicircular canal.
  • Mastoid antrum.
  • Internal auditory canal.
  • Tympanic cavity.
  • Cochlea.
  • External auditory canal.

The image below shows Towne's view 

Submentovertical view (also known as the basal view or Hirtz view) is taken with vertex near the film and X-ray beam projected at right angles to the film from the submental area.

 Structures seen are:
  • Sphenoid, posterior ethmoid, and maxillary sinuses (seen best in that order).
  • Zygoma.
  • Zygomatic arch.
  • Mandible along with coronoid and condyloid processes.
  • External auditory canal.
  • Middle ear cleft, i.e. mastoid cells, middle ear, and eustachian tube.
  • Internal auditory canal.

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: Identify the heart chamber marked in the given CT image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above CT image is the left atrium.

Transverse CT images are to be observed from the foot end of the supine patient, as if we are sitting at the patient's feet. So the right-hand side of the observer corresponds to the left-hand side in the CT.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with persistent fever and productive cough with purulent foul-smelling sputum for 6 weeks associated with night sweats and anemia. The following is his CXR. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described along with the chest X-ray image showing air–fluid level is suggestive of a lung abscess .

The patients usually present with complaints of fever, cough with sputum production and chest pain. Patients with putrid lung abscesses may report foul-smelling sputum. Patients with chronic lung abscess usually have a history of night sweats, fatigue, and anemia.

On physical examination, poor dentition/gingival disease, amphoric and/or cavernous breath sounds on lung auscultation, digital clubbing and the absence of a gag reflex are commonly seen.

CXR features of lung abscess:

  • A lung cavity with an air-fluid level
  • The cavity wall is thick and irregular, and a surrounding pulmonary-infiltrate is often present.

The two x-ray images given below show thick-walled cavities with air-fluid levels on lateral and PA views respectively.

questions.text: A mother brings her 9-year-old child with complaints of polyuria. On examination, he has growth failure and bitemporal hemianopia. Laboratory evaluation reveals low urine osmolality and high plasma osmolality. Findings on the MRI brain are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the MRI showing intracranial mass with foci of calcification at sella turcica and the laboratory findings suggestive of diabetes insipidus point to a diagnosis of craniopharyngioma.

Craniopharyngiomas are tumors that arise from the remnants of Rathke’s pouch. It is an intracranial space-occupying lesion. It has bimodal age of presentation. Children usually present with frequent headaches, short stature, bitemporal hemianopsia (due to optic chiasm compression), and polyuria.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol-rich, thick brownish-yellow fluid and are compared to machine oil. They also show radiologically demonstrable calcification.

Diabetes insipidus in these patients can be diagnosed with features such as polyuria, low urine osmolality, and high plasma osmolality. Treatment of central diabetes insipidus caused by craniopharyngioma includes supplementation with vasopressin analogs such as desmopressin (DDAVP) and resection of the tumor.

Other options:

Option B: Germinomas of the pituitary stalk also cause central diabetes insipidus. However, they are often missed in routine neuroimaging. 

Option C: Pituitary microadenomas usually present incidentally or with endocrine effects. They are <10mm in size and the tumor is confined to the sella. Visual field deficits are usually caused by pituitary macroadenomas. 

Option D: Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare cause of central diabetes insipidus. Symptoms include dermatological manifestations such as red, scaly papules, pain, and swelling in the limbs, characteristic bony lesions, and disseminated lymph node enlargement.

Related Pearl: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

Acquired

  • Head trauma (closed and penetrating) including pituitary surgery
  • Neoplasms
  • Granulomas
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Histiocytosis
  • Infectious
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Inflammatory
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Lupus erythematosus
    • Scleroderma
  • Vascular
    • Sheehan’s syndrome
    • Aneurysm (internal carotid)

Congenital

  • Malformations
  • Genetic
    • Wolfram syndrome

questions.text: The following appearance in IVP is caused by:
questions.solution:
The given IVP depicts the cobra head or adder head deformity or spring onion sign seen in bilateral ureterocele. It refers to dilatation of the distal ureter, surrounded by a thin lucent line seen in adult-type, uncomplicated ureterocoele. 

Ureterocele refers to the congenital dilatation of the distal-most portion of the ureter. The dilated portion of the ureter may herniate into the bladder secondary to an abnormal VUJ (vesicoureteric junction).
